Award.AwardTitle: FSML: Outdoor research garden and rainwater collection system at Tyson Research Center
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds a research garden and rainwater collection system at Washington University's environmental field station, the Tyson Research Center (TRC) in Eureka, MO. TRC's website is www.tyson.wustl.edu. The garden complements other recent improvements at TRC that are substantially increasing research productivity in landscape-scale manipulative ecological research, terrestrial plant ecology and aquatic ecology; teaching activity including research experiences for undergraduates; and public outreach integrated with ongoing research. In addition to this recent increase in research and outreach in the environmental sciences, TRC's commitment to sustainable facilities has led to a recent diversification of TRC's user base, which now includes architects, engineers, and artists, in addition to natural scientists. A recent facilities plan identified the research garden and rainwater collection system as high priority improvements needed to fully exploit the scientific and educational opportunities made possible by the other improvements.

In conjunction with current renovation and construction projects in progress, the research garden provides a centralized, interdisciplinary research space that brings together researchers from their various and widely-separated field sites, allowing for greater opportunities for collaboration while supporting several NSF-funded research projects. Additionally, the centralized location of the garden allows for greater teaching and outreach opportunities by bringing a part of the field research at TRC into view of student researchers, outreach visitors, and visiting members of the public. Finally, this accessible, easy-to-use experimental space benefits TRC's NSF-funded informal science education program by providing new opportunities for including experimentation in field courses.

Performance_Institution.Name: Tyson Research Center, Washington University in St. Louis

POR.DRECONTENT:
Environmental research stations (“field stations”) are critical resources for conducting scientific explorations on a variety of key factors affecting ecosystems, biodiversity, conservation, and the value of the environment to society. Field stations can be centers of discovery and innovation, providing locations that exist in perpetuity for the purpose of examining and understanding the world in which we live. Washington University in St. Louis’s field station, Tyson Research Center (TRC), is undergoing a growth of activity fueled by investment of resources from the University, together with increasing usage by faculty, students, and other career scientists from Washington University and other institutions in the St. Louis area and beyond. TRC is a ~2000 acre field station located in the Missouri Ozarks, composed of primarily naturally occurring oak-hickory forest, together with experimental glades and prairies. Facilities include a Living Building-certified classroom and office building, a ~4,000 ft2 laboratory building completed in 2013, and a newly renovated headquarters facility. Until approximately 2013, research at was nearly exclusively field-based, but a site analysis and user survey indicated a tangible need for a large research garden to complement work being conducted in field research sites across the station property.

As a result, TRC constructed a >8,000 ft2 research garden with a rainwater collection system through the support of the NSF Field Station and Marine Labs program (NSF DBI-1319180). The research garden allows ecologists to conduct experiments with plant communities, soil microbes, and a variety of other species by creating a growing space where environmental factors such as sunlight, precipitation, pollination, and temperature can be manipulated and controlled. Importantly, these manipulations can provide very robust ways to tease apart mechanisms driving observations made in field-based research projects. For example, TRC supports a forest dynamics plot that is part of the Smithsonian Institute’s ForestGEO program (Forest Global Earth Observatory). Within this plot, researchers have been monitoring abundance, size, dispersal, functional traits, and mortality of tree species with changes in climate and drought intensity across the ~60 acre plot. This highly intensive project has revealed patterns in forest dynamics with environmental change, but experiments that manipulate components of the environment that are hypothesized to drive such changes are critical to making conclusions about mechanisms for such affects. The research garden allows a place to do just that.

The research garden is composed of 5, 27’ by 60’ sections containing a prairie-type soil to a depth of 3’ over 1’ of limestone gravel for drainage. Each garden section is accessed via walkways composed of trap rock, and irrigated with frost-free hydrants supplying water from a 20,000 gallon capacity rainwater collection system that captures rainwater from the roof of a warehouse adjacent to the garden. Since construction of the garden was completed, three WUSTL faculty, two graduate students, five undergraduates, and two high school interns have undertaken collaborative research in the garden, utilizing nearly all available research space. Projects include measuring functional traits in saplings (complementary to research in the forest dynamics plot), evaluating the genetic basis for local adaptation in white clover, and plant-soil feedbacks driving disease prevalence in plant communities. We anticipate many discoveries to be facilitated by the TRC research garden, particularly via supplementing work conducted at broad spatial extents in the field.
